 I've been thinking about this a lot in the last couple of days, I could probably write a few pages, but I'm going to try and keep it real short.
 
 I think there was two MAIN functions in society that religion performed - 
 
 1- explanation of the "unexplainable"
 
 2- the codification and enforcment of a moral and ethical standard of behaviour.
 
 I think there's a long list of other functions and purposes that religion served or was corrupted to serve as well, but I'll leave them out for now.
 
 Given that we have the knowledge and capability of modern science, we'd no longer need religion for #1. Much of the NT and most myths of Native American peoples and other similar myths which seek to explain nature would be completely unnecessary, and would likely not be contrived again. However, science can still not answer as fact how life and the universe came to be, therefore, I believe there would be those that would still attribute this to a higher power. Whether that power would take on the form of an intelligent, emotional, omnipotent "human like" being I don't know. IMHO, I doubt it.
 
 Secondly, I know that much of today's ethics and laws are rooted in Christianity, however, ASSUMING that our current morality and laws are retained, there would be no need for a religion to reinforce them IMHO. 
 
 In essence, my feeling is that there would be very little or no "organized" religion. We wouldn't have the need to seek out explanation of the natural world or law and order through religion, so the organized, dogmatic approach to religion would be lost IMHO. However, humanity would likely seek to find a spiritual answer to questions like Where did life begin? What is the meaning of life? What happens when we die? etc...
 
 Like unkerpaulie, I think tradition is the only thing holding formal organized religion (and religion as a whole for that matter) together at this point, and IMHO, it's influence will continue to decrease as mankind continues to "evolve" and become more global in our understanding of others and our environment. 
 
 Great thread Anastasia, I hope it keeps rolling.

 After a short think on this, I believe we would eventually get to about the same state we're in now regarding religions. It might take longer because we'd already know a lot of the things that were puzzling to those ignorant people thousands of years ago who started with no knowledge at all. Fear of the unknown is likely a big part of what drove development of religions in the early stages. (It may drive some people today.)
 
 We'd certainly have leaders and people we respect a great deal, and look up to, and honor, and obey, and serve. There'd be some hierarchy and protocol to follow, maybe some bowing down. We'd still mourn the deaths of loved ones and great leaders. We'd wonder what happened to them after death. We'd want it to be a pleasant (heavenly) thing. We'd envision a heavenly place where we live again, but then forever. We'd think about who controls it and we'd come up with a supreme being...maybe not as one group of people coming to recognize one supreme being, but as multitudes of groups coming up each with its own version of a supreme being. Notwithstanding the fact that we wouldn't remember g-o-d as a word, we'd likely come up with a name.
 
 This question will produce entirely different answers between an atheist and a theist, even though we'd actually all become atheists when the hypothetical great memory dump happened. The atheists likely think man invented God because he was ignorant of science and would have had no need of religion had the scientific knowledge come first.
 
 The above is just my opinion.
 
 
 However, what I really KNOW as a matter of fact would happen is that God would thump our collective noggins and jog our memories. He will not be forgotten! I wouldn't know that immediately following the global memory loss, but my answer is based on what I know now.
 
 (By the way, a previous poster who wanted to start a thread like this but with the disappearance of books and stuff brought up a good point. If we lose our memories but not the jillions of existing copies of the bible and the jillions of existing religious films and pamphlets, we'd read our way back in a short while.
